q.#text:

							Sparta has mony a mon better than him.

Father, the miserable
							foreigner will be your ruin if you don't get him out of
							the house pretty soon!

p.#text:
Gorgo, daughter of king Cleomenes, when
						Aristagoras of Miletus was urging her father to enter
						upon the war against the Persian king in behalf of
						the Ionians, promising a vast sum of money, and, in
						answer to Cleomenes' objections, making the amount
						larger and larger, said,

It is because he showed me how to make the wine

								more wine drunk, and the drinkers will become more

note.#text: the note on , 218 d (4), where the same idea is attributed to Archidamus.

						shoes put on and laced by one of the servants, she
						said,

q.#text:
Get away from here, you who cannot play a
							woman's part either!

p.#text:
When a foreigner made advances in a mild
						and leisurely way, she pushed him aside, saying,

q.#text:
Why is
						it that you Spartan women are the only women that
						lord it over your men,

Because we are
							the only women that are mothers of men.

p.#text: Being asked by a woman from Attica,  she said,

q.#text:
Marry a good man, and
							bear good children.

p.#text:
As she was encouraging her husband Leonidas,
						when he was about to set out for Thermopylae, to
						show himself worthy of Sparta, she asked what she
						should do; and he said,

q.#text:
Will you not stop
							your noise ? He has shown from what blood he was
							sprung.

note.#text: The last sentence is borrowed from Plato, , 604 c.

p.#text:
Gyrtias, when on a time Acrotatus, her grandson, in a fight with other boys received many blows,
						and was brought home for dead, and the family and
						friends were all wailing, said,  And she said that people who were good
						for anything should not scream, but should try to
						find some remedy.

note.#text: Son of Areus I., king of Sparta. He fell in battle at Megalopolis in 265 bc., but the fact that hsi father Areus had been fighting in Crete may account for the intrusion of Crete here. Pausanias (viii. 27. 11) makes a more serious error in confusing this Acrotatus with his grandfather of the same name.
the similar saying of a Spartan woman, quoted by Teles in Stobaeus, , cviii. 83.

When
							he had come to the enemy, was he not bound either
							to be slain by them or to slay them ? It is more
							pleasing to hear that he died in a manner worthy of
							myself, his country, and his ancestors than if he had
							lived for all time a coward.

Another, hearing that her son had fallen on the

							of this or stop yer living.

Another, hearing that her son had been saved
						and had run away from the enemy, wrote to him,

q.#text:
Where have you
							come now in your cowardly flight, vile varlets ? Do
							you intend to slink in here whence you came forth?

note.#text: , 246 a, and Teles as quoted by Stobaeus, , cviii. 83.

All have perished,

							so they sent you to bear the bad news to us!

Isn't it a
							shame, then, to have missed his company on such a

p.#text:
As a man was narrating to his mother the
						noble death of his brother, she said,

q.#text:
I did not inquire about that, you vile varlet, but
							how fares our country ?
Then,

I accept
							gladly also the death of my sons.

p.#text:
One woman sent forth her sons, five in number,
						to war, and, standing in the outskirts of the city, she
						awaited anxiously the outcome of the battle. And
						when someone arrived and, in answer to her inquiry,
						reported that all her sons had met death, she said,
						
						
						
						             And when he declared
						that it was victorious,  she said,

Ah the
						bad luck of it, you puir woman.
No, by Heaven,

but good luck; for I bore him that he
							might die for Sparta, and this is the very thing that
							has come to pass for me.

note.#text: The story is told also by Teles in Stobaeus, , cviii. 83;  also Cicero, , i. 42 (102).

							and it is over these that she should be elated and
							boastful.

note.#text: Severus in Stobaeus, , v. 47, and the similar story of the Roman Cornelia, the mother of the Gracchi.

When a woman from Ionia showed vast pride in
						a bit of her own weaving, which was very valuable, a
						Spartan woman pointed to her four sons, who were
						most well-behaved, and said,

q.#text:
Ill report is spread about ye; pit this from ye
							or else stop yer living.

p.#text:
Another, hearing about her son that he was
						conducting himself badly in a foreign land, wrote to
						him,

q.#text:
Mither to Paedaretus. Aither dae better,
							or stay whare ye are, and gie up hope o' gaen back
							safe to Sparta.

p.#text:
Of somewhat similar character is this : Chian
						exiles came to Sparta, and accused Paedaretus of
						many misdeeds; whereupon his mother Teleutia
						sent for them and, after listening to their complaints,
						feeling that her son was in the wrong, sent him this
						letter :

q.#text:
My child, either rid yourself
							of the charges, or rid yourself of life.

p.#text:
Another, when her son was being tried for some
						offence, said to him,

q.#text:
At every step,
							my child, remember your valour.

p.#text:
Another, as she accompanied a lame son on
						his way to the field of battle, said,

q.#text:
If you remember your valour, my child,
							you will feel no pain, and be quite cheerful.

p.#text:
Another, when her son came back to her from
						the field of battle wounded in the foot, and in great
						pain, said,

q.#text:
How much better to be joyful over your bravery
							rather than to be mortified at silly laughter.

p.#text:
A Spartan, wounded in battle and unable to
						walk, was crawling on all fours. He was mortified at
						being so ridiculous; but his mother said to him,

q.#text: Either this or upon this.

note.#text: Referred to Gorgo as the author by Aristotle in his , as quoted by Stobaeus, , vii. 31, but it is often spoken of as a regular Spartan custom. , for example, the scholium on Thucydides, ii. 39. Ancient writers were not agreed whether the second half meant to fall upon the shield (dead or wounded) or to be brought home dead upon it. In support of the second (traditional) interpretation , 235 a, and Valerius Maximus, ii. 7, ext. 2.

Another, as she handed her son his shield,
						exhorted him, saying,

This
							shield your father kept always safe for you; do you,
							therefore, keep it safe, or cease to live.

						said, as she gave the shield into his hands,

Add a
							step to it.

						said,

Lay him away, and let his brother take his
							place.

p.#text:
Another, hearing that her son had been killed
						in battle on the spot where he had been placed,
						said,

q.#text:
How much more noble, my
							friends, to be victorious on the field of battle and meet
							death, than to win at the Olympic games and live!

note.#text: the somewhat similar story about Xenophon in , 118 f.

p.#text:
Another, engaged in conducting a solemn public procession, heard that her son was victorious on the
						field of battle, but that he was dying from the many
						wounds he had received. She did not remove the
						garland from her head, but with a proud air said to
						the women near her,

q.#text:
As glad as I am for him,
							I am sorry for you that you were left behind when
							you might have gone in such brave company.

p.#text:
As a man was relating to his sister the noble
						death of her son, she said,

q.#text:
When I was a child I learned to obey my
							father, and made that my practice. Then when I
							became a married woman, my husband took that
							place. So if the man's proposal is honourable, let
							him lay the matter before my husband first.

p.#text:
A man sent to a Spartan woman to ask if she
						were inclined to look with favour upon seduction; she
						replied,

q.#text:
The family
							virtue.

p.#text:
A poor girl, being asked what dowry she brought
						to the man who married her, said,

q.#text:
No, but my husband
							has made them to me.

p.#text:
A Spartan woman, being asked if she had made
						advances to her husband, said,

div2.p:
A girl had secret relations with a man, and,
						after bringing on an abortion, she bore up so bravely,
						not uttering a single sound, that her delivery took
						place without the knowledge of her father and
						others who were near. For the confronting of her
						indecorum with decorum gained the victory over the
						poignant distress of her pains.

q.#text: To be faithful.

p.#text:
A Spartan woman who was being sold as a
						slave, when asked what she knew how to do, said,

q.#text: To manage a house well.

p.#text:
Another, taken captive, and asked a similar
						question, said,

q.#text:
Yes, and if you do not buy
							me.

p.#text:
Another, asked by a man if she would be good
						if he bought her, said,

q.#text: To be free.

You will be sorry that your meanness has cost
							you such a possession,
